title: 110_hr1700
content: The Act titled "COPS Improvements Act of 2007" focuses on improving COPS grants. The COPS Improvements Act of 2007 amends Section 1701 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to authorize the Attorney General to make grants for community policing and crime prevention programs. The COPS Improvements Act of 2007 amends Section 1701 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to authorize grants for community policing and crime prevention programs, including hiring officers for intelligence, anti-terror, and homeland security duties, school resource officers, and establishing school-based partnerships with law enforcement agencies to combat crime in schools. The COPS Improvements Act of 2007 authorizes grants for community policing and crime prevention programs, including innovative programs to reduce illegal drug activities and criminal gang enforcement task forces involving Federal, State, and local law enforcement authorities. The COPS Improvements Act of 2007 authorizes grants for community policing and crime prevention programs, including hiring former military personnel as law enforcement officers for community-oriented policing. The Attorney General may provide grants for community prosecuting programs to address specific crime issues, including counter-terrorism, violent crime, illegal gang activities, and drug enforcement in areas affected by military base closures. Former military personnel can be hired as law enforcement officers for community-oriented policing. The Attorney General may provide grants for community prosecuting programs to address specific crime issues, including counter-terrorism, violent crime, illegal gang activities, and drug enforcement in areas affected by military base closures. Grants may also be used for technology development to assist law enforcement agencies in preventing crime and training officers in new technologies. In paragraph (2), the Office of Community Oriented Policing Services shall establish functions. Paragraph (3) includes training centers or facilities (including regional community policing institutes). The Office of Community Oriented Policing Services is the exclusive component of the Department of Justice for specified functions. The Office of Community Oriented Policing Services of the Department of Justice shall be used in carrying out specified functions. Amendments are made to subsections (h) and (i) regarding fiscal year allocations and federal contribution requirements. Amendments are made to federal contribution requirements for hiring or rehiring officers under grant programs, with a minimum non-Federal share of costs set at 25% for the entire grant period. This requirement does not apply to grants made under subsection (b)(4). Amendments to federal grant programs require grant recipients to retain additional law enforcement officer positions created under the grant for at least 12 months after the grant period, unless waived by the Attorney General. Additionally, changes are made to application requirements, with a 25% non-Federal share of costs for the entire grant period, except for grants under subsection (b)(4). Amendments to federal grant programs now require grant recipients to maintain increased hiring levels of law enforcement officers and eventually assume full responsibility for all costs. Section 1703 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to address grant renewal. "Section 1703 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to address grant renewal." Grant renewals under this part may be granted without limitations on duration if funds were used as required and significant progress was made. Grants for hiring law enforcement officers can be renewed for up to 5 years, with a waiver possible for good cause. The Attorney General can also provide no-cost extensions to complete grant objectives. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to limit the use of funds for grants under this part. The Attorney General can determine the availability of funds from State or local sources for the grant purposes. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include a scientific study of program effectiveness in reducing crime. The Attorney General will select institutions of higher education to conduct the study and provide reports within 4 years. The COPS Improvements Act of 2007 mandates a study on program effectiveness in reducing crime, with selected institutions reporting findings to the Attorney General for submission to Congress. Enforcement actions under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 are amended to include broader measures beyond funding revocation or suspension. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include broader enforcement actions beyond funding suspension, with authorization of appropriations increased for fiscal years 2008 through 2013. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to allocate specific amounts for grants under different sections, with a focus on technical assistance and grant purposes specified in section 1701(b). The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to improve the COPS Program by making changes to sections 109(b) and 107 related to law enforcement computer systems. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to exempt grants made under part Q of the title from certain provisions. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to exempt grants made under part Q of the title from certain provisions. Additionally, a report by the Inspector General is required. The Inspector General of the Department of Justice must submit a report to Congress on the effectiveness and funding of the COPS ON THE BEAT grant program, including its impact on crime rates and any instances of waste, fraud, or abuse. The Inspector General of the Department of Justice must conduct random audits of State and local law enforcement agencies to detect any waste, fraud, or abuse within the program. The sampling will include agencies of different sizes, serving various populations, and areas with different crime rates. Passed the House of Representatives on May 15, 2007. Attest: LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk.
